data.response:
You're trying to inject an XSS (Cross-Site Scripting) attack.

In JavaScript, the `<script>` tag is used to define a new script, but when used with user-inputted content, it can be vulnerable to XSS attacks. However, in this case, the code you've provided will not work as intended.

The reason is that the HTML entity `&#x27;` is not being interpreted as a JavaScript string literal. In HTML, `&#x27;` represents an apostrophe character. When used in a context where it's not expected (like inside a `<script>` tag), it will be treated as plain text and displayed as such.

To successfully execute an XSS attack, you would need to use a more sophisticated technique, such as injecting JavaScript code using HTML entities that are properly interpreted by the browser, like `<script>` instead of `&#x3C;script>`.

Here's an example of how you might attempt to execute an XSS attack using the correct syntax:

```
<script>alert('XSS')</script>
```

This code would display an alert box with the message "XSS" when executed.
